title-group.article-title: An Empirical Evaluation of Behavioral Models Based on Decompositions of Stock Prices*

contrib-group.aff: College of Business, Florida State University

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2006 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: Several behavioral models have been proposed to explain the observed short‐horizon continuation and long‐horizon reversals in returns. We employ a time‐series framework of identifying tangible and intangible information based on two valuation models: the conventional dividend discount model and the residual income model. We find investors overreact to intangible information but underreact initially to tangible information, with no significant reversal associated with tangible information in the long run. Our finding is compatible with models incorporating investors’ overconfidence in their private information. We also find that the residual income model provides a better valuation than the dividend discount model.

fn.p: I am grateful to Albert Madansky and an anonymous referee for their insightful comments. I benefited from discussions with Alex Chuang, John Jiang, and Jaeuk Khil, while retaining the responsibility for any remaining errors. Contact the author at blee2@cob.fsu.edu.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Empirical studies have documented that asset returns can be predictable, based on publicly available information. Recent studies also document that stock returns appear to exhibit continuation or momentum in the short to medium term but a tendency to reverse in the long run. This observation is made not only for individual stock returns but also for portfolio returns.1

Specifically, empirical studies have produced some evidence of continuation (or momentum) in short holding period returns. Several studies of aggregate time series report that strong positive autocorrelations in short holding period returns, which is consistent with the underreaction hypothesis (see Lo and MacKinlay 1988; Poterba and Summers 1988; Cutler, Poterba, and Summers 1991).2For cross‐sectional evidence, Bernard (1992) surveys the underreaction of stock prices to announcements of earnings (see also Bernard and Thomas1989). Further evidence of momentum is provided by Jegadeesh and Titman (1993), who examine a cross‐section of U.S. stock returns and find a positive autocorrelation over a 6‐month horizon.

Concerning the predictability over long horizons, Fama and French (1988), Poterba and Summers (1988), and Cutler et al. (1991) find, over 3‐to 5‐year horizons, a negative autocorrelation in aggregate stock index returns in many markets. As such, they conclude that there is substantial mean‐reversion in stock market prices at longer horizons. For the cross section of stock returns, De Bondt and Thaler (1985) discover that portfolios of stocks with extremely poor returns over the previous 5 years dramatically outperform portfolios of stocks with extremely high returns, even after making the standard risk adjustments. Their finding is confirmed by later works (e.g., Chopra, Lakonishok, and Ritter1992).

Since these findings are not easily compatible with traditional asset pricing models, some are turning to behavioral models that involve some departure from the classical assumptions of strict rationality on the part of investors. Recent examples include papers by Barberis, Shleifer, and Vishny (1998), Daniel, Hirshleifer, and Subrahmanyam (1998), and Odean (1998).3They examine the extent to which these biases are sufficient to deliver both short‐horizon continuation and long‐horizon reversals. Barberis et al. (1998) offer an explanation for under‐ and overreactions based on a learning model in which actual earnings follow a random walk, but individuals believe that earnings either follow a steady growth trend or are mean reverting. Daniel et al. (1998) develop a theory based on investor overconfidence and changes in confidence resulting from biased self‐attribution of investment outcomes. Their central theme is that stock prices overreact to private information signals and underreact to public signals. Odean (1998) emphasizes that overconfidence affects financial markets. From evidence in psychological literature, he infers that people tend to underweigh abstract, statistical, and highly relevant information and overweigh salient, anecdotal, and extreme information, which may be related to under‐ and overreactions (see also Gervais and Odean2001). On the other hand, Hong and Stein (1999) model a market populated by two groups of boundedly rational agents: news watchers and momentum traders. They emphasize the interaction between heterogeneous agents, neither of whom is fully rational in the usual sense. If information diffuses gradually across the population, they show that prices underreact in the short run and overreact in long horizons.

Daniel and Titman (2005) provide a recent attempt to test these models. They define tangible information as explicit performance measures, such as sales, earnings, and cash flows, which can be observed in the firm's accounting statements. Intangible information, in contrast, is the part of the stock's past returns that cannot be linked directly to accounting numbers but presumably reflect changes in expectations about future cash flows. They show that the distinction between tangible and intangible information is useful for distinguishing among various behavioral models.4

We generalize and extend Daniel and Titman's (2005) identification of tangible and intangible information to a more flexible, dynamic context. Our framework enables us to examine the market's reactions to each type of information over time and the relative importance of two types of information over different horizons. Therefore, we can address continuation and reversal over time in a dynamic context and shed light on the various behavioral models in the literature. To identify the tangible and intangible information, we employ two valuation models: the conventional dividend discount model (DDM) and the accounting‐based residual income model (RIM). The RIM has recently become popular in accounting literature,5and several studies have found that the RIM provides a better valuation than the conventional DDM.6As a by‐product of identifying these two types of information based on the two valuation models, we reexamine another very important issue: the relative performance of these valuation models.

Unlike the behavioral models, there is a growing literature that explores how asset return predictability could arise from rational agents (e.g., Jones and Slezak1998; Grundy and Kim2002; Holden and Subrahmanyam2002). Typically, these models rely on some combination of risk aversion and information asymmetry. We explore their empirical implications based on our identification framework.

The paper is organized as follows. InSection II, we provide further background of this study. InSection III, we introduce the accounting‐based residual income model as an alternative valuation model to the conventional dividend discount model. We discuss the identification of tangible and intangible information (or components) based on bivariate models of the DDM and RIM. Then, we discuss identification based on trivariate models allowing for time‐varying discount factors.Section IVbriefly describes the data and presents preliminary results.Section Vdiscusses empirical results on the market's reactions to tangible and intangible information and the relative importance of each type of information and components in stock prices over different time horizons.Section VIconcludes the paper.

fn.p: For example, Daniel, Hirshleifer, and Subrahmanyam (1998, pp. 1839–40) list a positive short‐term autocorrelation of returns (short‐term momentum) and a negative autocorrelation of returns (long‐term reversal) as some pervasive anomalies that need to be explained.

Cutler et al. (1991) examine autocorrelations in excess returns on various indexes over different horizons and find positive autocorrelations in excess returns over horizons of between 1 month and 1 year. Rouwenhorst (1997) documents the presence of momentum in international equity markets.
Cutler, Poterba, and Summers (1990) introduce some irrational traders, such as feedback traders, and the market's slow adjustment to fundamentals (see also Delong et al.1990).

Daniel and Titman (2005) argue that the distinction between tangible and intangible information is also motivated by existing psychological evidence consistent with the idea that individuals react differently to information that is difficult to interpret. Specifically, individuals tend to be more overconfident in settings where more judgment is required to evaluate information and the feedback on the quality of this judgment is ambiguous in the short run (Einhorn1980).

The idea of the RIM dates back to the work of Preinreich (1938) and Edwards and Bell (1961). However, it has recently become more popular due primarily to its formalization by Ohlson (1991,1995) and Feltham and Ohlson (1995).
For example, see Penman and Sougiannis (1998), Dechow, Hutton, and Sloan (1999), Lee, Myers, and Swaminathan (1999), Francis, Olsson, and Oswald (2000), and Jiang and Lee (2005).

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Background
sec.p: The main purpose is to shed light on the various behavioral models in the literature by using our framework. Daniel et al. (1998) make a distinction between public and private information, which is related to the distinction between tangible and intangible information. In their model, investors are overconfident about the precision of their private signals, and therefore, the market overreacts to intangible private information and underreacts to tangible public information.7Odean's (1998) model anticipates similar market reactions in that agents are more overconfident about diffuse information, which is likely to be intangible.

Barberis et al. (1998) present a parsimonious model of investor sentiment and how investors form expectations of future earnings. Their model is based on psychological evidence that, when making forecasts, people pay too much attention to the strength of the evidence they are presented with and too little attention to its statistical weight.8Thus, their model is based on the idea that investors misinterpret the pattern of information events such as earnings announcements.9

Hong and Stein (1999) model a market populated by news watchers and momentum traders. Because news diffuses slowly through the population of news watchers, prices underreact in the short run. This underreaction means that momentum traders can profit by trend chasing, which leads to overreaction at long horizons. One of the primary contributions of Hong and Stein (1999, p. 2165) is to show that the equilibrium impulse response to private information is hump shaped, with underreaction in the short run giving way to eventual overreaction. Regarding public news, they argue that their model also generates short‐run underreaction to public news.

Our analysis, based on vector autoregression (VAR) identification of tangible and intangible information, shows that the stock market tends to overreact to intangible information but underreact to tangible information, particularly in the short run. We do not find underreaction in the long run to either type of information.10If we interpret the tangible/intangible information as related to public/private information, as in Daniel and Titman (2005), our finding is compatible with the overconfidence hypothesis proposed by Odean (1998) and Daniel et al. (1998).11

At issue is whether reactions to tangible and intangible information are sensitive to the way we define (or identify) the two types of information. Daniel and Titman (2005) point out that one of their definitions of tangible information is the component of change in the firm's value (i.e., of the firm's return) that is attributable to its growth in book value. They define the projection of past returns onto book return as the tangible return and the residual from this projection (i.e., the component of the firm's return that cannot be explained by fundamentals) as the intangible return. That is, the tangible and intangible components are defined with respect to their relevance to book value (or return). As mentioned already, to identify tangible and intangible information, we employ the conventional DDM model and the RIM model. In the former, the two types of information are identified with respect to their relevance to dividends, whereas in the latter they are identified with respect to earnings and book value. It seems that the terminology of tangible and intangible information is loosely based on a behavioral finance interpretation, whereas that of fundamental and nonfundamental information is related to the conventional valuation model‐based interpretation (e.g., Lee1998).

Another issue is how to consider the risk of a stock that may be related to realizations of tangible and intangible information. This is because, for example, reaction to intangible information may potentially be generated (or influenced) by changes in risk that are highly correlated with tangible information. In our framework, tangible and intangible shocks (or information) are mutually exclusive because they are generated based on an orthogonalization of shocks. To allow for a risk factor, we consider trivariate models with a time‐varying discount factor by extending bivariate models. With the trivariate models, we still find, as in the bivariate models, that investors overreact to intangible information, but find no evidence of a significant reversal of returns associated with tangible information. That is, the risk factor does not appear to change our findings.

fn.p: In other words, they expect investors to put too little weight on tangible information relative to intangible information.

They suppose that earnings announcements represent information that is of low strength but significant statistical weight, which yields the prediction that stock prices underreact to earnings announcements and similar events. They further assume that consistent patterns of news, such as a series of good earnings announcements, represent information that is of high strength and low weight. This assumption yields a prediction that stock prices overreact to consistent patterns of good or bad news.

As such, as in Daniel and Titman (2005), their model may be interpreted in terms of investors’ overreaction to tangible information, such as earnings and sales, since their model predicts that news with more strength would generate a bigger reaction from investors. Barberis et al. (1998) state in their conclusion, “If news can be classified on a priori grounds, this prediction is testable. Specifically, the theory predicts that one‐time strong news events should generate an overreaction.”
Daniel and Titman (2005) find evidence that investors overreact to intangible information but find no evidence of a significant reversal of the returns associated with tangible information.

A more rigorous alternative approach would be to simulate artificial data (e.g., dynamic impulse responses) from (or calibrate) each model and then explicitly compare the model's implications with the data. We take the view that some behavioral models are not easily amenable to this approach.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: The Identification of Tangible and Intangible Components in Stock Prices

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Deriving the Residual Income Model

fn.p: More detailed derivations of various equations in this section are delegated to Appendix A.
Following Peasnell (1981) and others, the CSR implies that goodwill equals the present value of future expected abnormal earnings (see Ohlson1995).

sec.label: B.
sec.title: The Identification of Tangible and Intangible Components Based on Bivariate Models
The dividend discount model.
The residual income model.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: The Identification of Tangible and Intangible Components Based on Trivariate Models
The log‐linear dividend discount model with time‐varying interest rates.
sec.p: We assumed in the previous section that the discount rate is constant over time, so that the time‐varying discount rate does not enter models. In theory, the discount rate may play a potentially important role in the valuation models.14In this section, to allow for a risk factor, we consider trivariate models with time‐varying discount factors—the real interest rate in the DDM model and return on equity in the RIM model—as additional fundamental (i.e., tangible) variables and examine the tangible and intangible components of stock price movements in trivariate models.15

The log‐linear residual income model with time‐varying discount rates.To allow for a risk factor in the RIM model, we employ a version of the log‐linearized RIM with time‐varying discount rates recently developed by Vuolteenaho (2000,2002). He derives a book‐to‐market‐ratio‐based present‐value model using the clean surplus relation.18This may turn out to be an important extension of the RIM model, because unlike in the case of the DDM, the time‐varying discount rate in the RIM may affect not only the discount factor for the expected future residual income (see equation [4]) but also the level of residual income itself (see equation [3]).

fn.p: Changes in the discount rate could arise from changes in agents' marginal rates of substitution or changes in the conditional variance of innovations to the dividend process (due to changes in the conditional variance of the underlying earnings process). Some argue that the time‐varying discount rate may help explain the failure of the simple DDM model in explaining price volatility (e.g., Cochrane1992).
We may allow for time‐varying equity risk premia, which may require us to employ a four‐variable model.

For details, see eqq. (2)–(6) in Vuolteenaho (2000).

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Restricted TVAR Model
sec.p: The bivariate and trivariate moving average representation (models in (7), (11), (16), and (21) are obtained by first estimating bivariate (BVAR) and trivariate vector autoregressions (TVAR), then inverting them. Hence, inAppendix B, we discuss how to impose restrictions in (8), (12), (17), and (22) on the BVAR and the TVAR.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Data and Preliminary Results
sec.p: For an empirical estimation of the DDM and the RIM, we employ two types of aggregate index data: annual Dow Jones industrial average (DJIA) index data for the sample period 1920–1999, and annual Standard and Poor's (S&P) 400 industrial index data for the sample period 1946–99. We use aggregate index data in our analyses in part because over‐ and underreactions are also observed for aggregate index returns as well as cross‐sectional data, and in part because public/private and tangible/intangible information is likely to be more robust with aggregate index variables.

The annual DJIA index data come from the Value Line publication,A Long‐Term Perspective: Dow Jones Industrial Average.For the annual S&P index, the index prices, dividends, and earnings all come from the Standard and Poor's Statistical Service publication,Security Price Index Record.The price index is the December price. The index dividend series are dividends per share, a 12‐month moving total adjusted to the index for the last quarter of the year. The index earnings series are earnings per share, adjusted to index, 4‐quarter total, fourth quarter.19

For the variables used in the trivariate log‐linear model, the first‐differenced log dividends (Δd), Δdr,and the first‐differenced log earnings (Δx) are stationary for both the DJIA data and the S&P 400 index data. The return on equity (ar) appears to be stationary for the DJIA data. The spreads for both the DDM model (pd) and the RIM model (pb) appear to be nonstationary, which suggests that the deviation of log prices from the log‐linear models is quite substantial.

fn.p: The book value is kindly provided by Jeffrey Pontiff. For details, see Pontiff and Schall (1998).

This finding is not really surprising, given previous studies that find the spread based on the DDM model tends to be very persistent. Although we do not find evidence of stationarity in our finite sample, we still use this spread, in part because the model anticipates this spread, recognizing the DDM model's limitations.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: The Market's Reactions to Tangible and Intangible Information
sec.p:
Figure 1illustrates the market's reactions using the DJIA index data, measured in standard deviations, of stock prices to 1 standard deviation innovation in tangible and intangible shocks. These levels are derived by expanding the response of spreads as discussed in each proposition. Figure 1(a) shows the responses of DJIA index prices in the bivariate DDM model. While tangible (i.e., dividend) shocks have gradually increasing effects on prices, the effects of intangible shocks on prices are an initial increase for a year, followed by steady declines over time. This suggests a strong initial underreaction of prices to tangible (dividend) shocks and an overreaction to intangible shocks. In figure 1(b), which shows the responses of DJIA index prices in the bivariate RIM model, the effects of the tangible shocks stabilize in a few years, persisting for a long period after an initial increasing effect, while the effects of intangible shocks are short lived, declining close to 0 after an initial increase for a year. This again suggests an initial underreaction of the market to tangible information and overreaction to intangible information. Fig. 1.—
The market's reactions using the DJIA index data, measured in standard deviations, of stock prices to 1 standard deviation innovation in tangible and intangible shocks. Response of DJIA price to (a) dividend (series 1) and nonfundamental (series 2) shocks with a standard error band, based on DDM model; (b) residual income (series 1) and nonfundamental(series 2) shocks with a standard error band, based on RIM model; (c) dividend (series 1), interest rate (series 2), and nonfundamental (series 3) shocks with a standard error band, based on DDM model; and (d) earnings (series 1), book value (series 2), and nonfundamental (series 3) shocks with a standard error band, based on RIM model.

Figure 1(c) illustrates the responses of DJIA index prices in the trivariate DDM model. While tangible (i.e., dividend) shocks have rather stable, persistent effects on prices after a few years of initial underreaction by the market, the other tangible shock, interest rate shock, persistently has negative effects on prices with some initial underreaction. The effects of intangible shocks on prices steadily decline after an initial increase, showing strong overreaction by the market. Figure 1(d) illustrates the responses of DJIA index prices in the trivariate RIM model. While tangible (i.e., earnings) shocks persistently have positive effects on prices, after initial underreaction by the market, the other tangible shock, book value shock, has initial negative effects that reverse in a few years. The effects of intangible shocks on prices gradually decline after an initial increase as the forecasting horizon increases, showing overreaction by the market.

Figure 2(a) shows the responses of S&P index prices in the bivariate DDM model. Tangible (i.e., dividend) shocks have rather stable effects on prices after a few years, showing initial underreaction with no long‐run under‐ or overreactions. The effect of intangible shocks on prices increases over time, suggesting a gradual deviation of stock prices from tangibles (i.e., dividends) over long horizons. This may be related to a nonstationary spread in the model observed inSection IVand casts doubts on the bivariate DDM model. As we discuss later, we do not place too much weight on this response because we find the bivariate DDM model to be unreliable, particularly with the S&P data (seeSection V.B).22Infigure 2(b), which shows the responses of S&P index prices in the bivariate RIM model, the effects of the tangible shocks increase initially but stabilize in a few years, persisting for a long period, suggesting initial underreaction to tangible shocks with no long‐run under‐ or overreactions. The effects of intangible shocks are short lived, declining close to zero after initially positive effects. This suggests that the market initially overreacts to the intangible information, the intangible shocks have little effect on prices in the long run, and the tangible shocks based on residual income dominate the price fluctuations. This pattern of dynamic responses is very similar to the responses using DJIA data in figure 1(b). Fig. 2.—
The responses of (a) the S&P index price to dividend (series 1) and nonfundamental (series 2) shocks with a standard error band, based on DDM model; (b) the S&P index price to residual income (series 1) and nonfundamental (series 2) shocks with a standard error bans, based on RIM model; (c) the log of S&P price to dividend (series 1), interest rate (series 2), and nonfundamental shocks with a standard error band, based on DDM model; and (d) the log of the S&P index price to earnings (series 1), book value (series 2), and nonfundamental (series 3) shocks with a standard error band, based on RIM model.

Figure 2(c) illustrates the responses of S&P index prices in the trivariate DDM model. Tangible (i.e., dividend) shocks have quite stable, persistent effects on prices after some mild, initial underreaction by the market. The other tangible shock, interest rate shock, has quite persistent negative effects on prices with some initial underreaction by the market. After a strong initial response, the effects of intangible shocks on prices are quite persistent, showing a mild overreaction.Figure 2(d) illustrates the responses of S&P index prices in the trivariate RIM model. Tangible (i.e., earnings) shocks have gradually increasing effects on prices, suggesting initial undereactions by the market. The other tangible shock, book value shock (a denominator in the return on equity, or ROE), has a small negative effect initially, followed by a positive effect on prices. The effects of intangible shocks on prices decline very slowly as the forecasting horizon increases after an initial positive response, suggesting a mild overreaction by the market. The comparison withFigure 2(c) indicates that the effect of earnings information in the trivariate RIM is much stronger than that of dividends.

The result of overreaction to intangible information is considerably stronger for the DJIA index data than for the S&P index data. Given that the DJIA contains relatively large firms, followed by a large number of analysts and investors, the stronger overreaction by DJIA index prices suggests that, as more overconfident investors follow DJIA stocks, the DJIA index prices tend to overreact more strongly to intangible information.

fn.p: The figures also report one standard error band around the response. This is calculated using the Monte Carlo integration simulation method of computing the first and second moments of the posterior distribution of the orthonormalized impulse responses in the restricted VAR models.

Compared with Figure 1(a), which uses DJIA data, the effect of tangibles (i.e., dividends) is relatively strong with the DJIA data, implying the importance of dividends in larger companies that are members of the DJIA.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: The Relative Importance of Tangible and Intangible Information
sec.p: In addition to the dynamic effects of each type of information on stock prices to figure out possible under‐and overreactions by the market, it is both interesting and important to examine the relative importance of tangible and intangible information in affecting stock prices. If intangible information is insignificant relative to tangible information, it would not be useful to distinguish between the two. However, if intangible information dominates, even in the long run for either the DDM model or the RIM model, the model may be misspecified and may not capture tangible information sufficiently.

The results using DJIA index data are presented intable 2, and those using S&P index data are intable 3. Because the level of the market price index may be easier to interpret and more intuitive than the spread, we also present the decompositions for the levels of prices as discussed in each proposition. Panel D oftable 2presents the forecast error decompositions of the trivariate model of the log‐linearized RIM model with a time‐varying return on equity (ar). By construction, all variation in the first differenced log earnings (Δx) is explained by earnings’ own shocks. For the ROE, about 83–89% of variation is explained by earnings shocks, with the remaining less than 17% of variation being explained by book‐value shocks. This indicates that most of the variation in ROE is due to earnings changes rather than changes in book values.

sec.title: The S&P Index Data.
sec.p: To summarize, our models seem reasonable for our purpose of identifying tangible and intangible shocks (or components), in that the two types of shocks are well represented by the models, as shown in their forecast error decompositions. As such, using our models as a means to examine the over‐and underreaction based on dynamic impulse responses to the two types of shocks seems warranted. Between the DDM and the RIM, the tangibles in the RIM, earnings, contain more information about the price movement than dividends alone. Overall, our analysis shows that intangible shocks initially explain the majority of stock price variations, but their explanatory power declines as the time horizon increases, whereas the explanatory power of tangible shocks increases gradually as the time horizon increases. This suggests that, among other things, the stock market underreacts to tangible shocks and overreacts to intangible shocks.

fn.p: Compared to the bivariate DDM model, the fraction of stock prices explained by tangibles is significantly greater in the trivariate log‐linear DDM model, which is a significant improvement with a log‐linearization and time‐varying interest rates. Compared with the results using the DJIA index data, the role of dividends is substantially more important with the DJIA index data, as mentioned already.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Evaluation of Various Models
sec.p: Our findings indicate that, although there is some variation depending on models and data, the market tends to underreact initially to such tangible information about earnings and dividends with no significant under‐/overreaction in the long run. However, there is consistent evidence that the market tends to overreact to intangible information and reverse its reaction over time.

Daniel et al.'s (1988) model makes a distinction between public and private information, which is related to the distinction between tangible and intangible information. In their model, investors are overconfident about the precision of their private signals and, therefore, overreact to intangible private information and underreact to tangible public information. This implication appears to be compatible with our finding, although we do not find underreaction to tangible information in the long run. Odean's (1998) model anticipates similar market reactions because agents have been shown to be more overconfident about diffuse information, which is likely to be intangible. As such, models based on overconfidence in private information, such as the analysis of Odean and Daniel et al., appear to be most easily compatible with our findings.

Hong and Stein's (1999) model generates short‐run underreaction to public news, which is consistent with our findings. Their argument that the equilibrium impulse response to private information is hump shaped, with underreaction in the short run giving way to eventual overreaction, also seems compatible with our findings of reaction to intangible information, particularly using DJIA data.

As discussed previously, the Barberis et al. model is based on the idea that investors misinterpret the pattern of information events, such as earnings announcements. Since the earnings announcement is a quarterly event, our use of annual data is not directly applicable for evaluating the Barberis et al. model. Further, they are exploring an extrapolation bias, wherein traders see patterns in random sequence. As such, it is not very clear how their model is related to the dynamic impulse responses of prices to the two types of innovations.

In addition, we find that the deviation of stock market prices from such market tangibles as dividends is very substantial with the bivariate DDM, particularly using S&P index data. However, the deviation is relatively small when we employ the RIM with such tangibles as residual income and book value or when we use DJIA index data, in which dividends play a relatively more important role as tangibles. As expected, in trivariate log‐linear models, interest rates have a weak, negative effect on stock market prices. In addition, the initial effect of book value in excess of earnings is relatively small and negative when compared with other tangibles, such as earnings or dividends.

As mentioned in the introduction, a growing literature explores how asset return predictability can arise from rational agents by relying on some combination of risk aversion and information asymmetry (e.g., Jones and Slezak1998; Grundy and Kim2002; Holden and Subrahmanyam2002). Our analysis sheds some light on these alternative explanations. For example, Jones and Slezak (1998) investigated the implications of asymmetric information on both cross‐sectional and dynamic properties of asset returns. In their multiasset dynamic rational expectations model, in addition to the informed and uninformed agents are liquidity (noise) traders who trade randomly and not on the basis of private or inferred information, and the liquidity shocks are assumed to be independent of news shocks. As a result of liquidity shocks, the model can generate both positive and negative serial correlation in equilibrium. If we regard the liquidity trading shock as an intangible shock in our framework, our finding is compatible with theirs to the extent that the liquidity shock can generate an initial increase in price followed by decreases.

Grundy and Kim (2002) developed an infinite‐horizon noisy rational expectations model. Using calibrations and simulations of the model, they find that a substantial excessive variability of prices (e.g., 20–46%) is induced by the heterogeneity of traders’ private information. If we regard the heterogeneity in traders’ private information about dividends (fundamentals) as due mainly to the intangible information in our framework, their finding is compatible with ours to the extent that the intangible shock (or component) explains a substantial fraction of price forecast error variance.

Holden and Subrahmanyam (2002) developed a model that accounts for medium‐term continuation (momentum) in asset returns, by analyzing information acquisition about news (such as earnings announcements) in a multiperiod setting. In their model, conditional risk premia related to early liquidity shocks gradually decrease, as agents sequentially receive private information about a future public announcement. If the mass of informed agents is sufficiently high because of a low cost of information acquisition, they obtain positive serial correlation. Their model can be compatible with our framework to the extent that the early liquidity shocks can be regarded as intangible information, which tends to generate an initial increase in price generating a positive serial correlation in returns.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Summary and Concluding Remarks
sec.p: By now, financial economists recognize that asset returns can be predictable based on publicly available information. In particular, returns appear to exhibit continuation or momentum in the short to medium term but tend to reverse in the long run. This is observed not only for individual stock returns but also portfolio returns. Since conventional asset pricing models cannot easily explain these empirical regularities, several alternative models, some of which are based on behavioral models, have been proposed.

We examined the empirical implications of these models. We employed a time‐series framework of identifying tangible and intangible (or fundamental and nonfundamental) information based on two widely used valuation models. We found strong evidence that investors overreact to intangible information but underreact initially to tangible information. We find no evidence of a significant reversal of the returns associated with tangible information, particularly in the long run. Our findings are quite robust with regard to the various valuation models we employ and the data we use. Our findings are most compatible with the overconfidence hypothesis (e.g., Daniel et al.1998; Odean1998). This implies that, among other things, investor overconfidence in private information and the distinction between tangible and intangible (or public and private) information are important in understanding the market's reactions. It may be possible for other models to explain our findings by allowing for additional features, such as overconfidence in private information. In addition, we find that allowing for a risk factor does not significantly change our findings, suggesting its minor role in our context. We also showed that our analysis sheds some light on alternative explanations, which rely on some combination of risk aversion and information asymmetry.

As a by‐product of our test procedure employing both the conventional DDM and the accounting‐based RIM, we find that the residual income model, which has become popular recently in the accounting literature, provides a better valuation than the conventional dividend discount model, which is consistent with recent findings.24This implies that accounting earnings and book values, although incomplete, contain substantially more information about stock prices than dividends alone. This may help explain why some studies find that such earning‐based ratios asE/PandB/Mhelp predict stock returns.

Daniel and Titman (2005) raised an interesting question as to whether we can identify a purely noise component in the intangible component of stock prices.25We conjecture that the pure noise component may not be substantial, given that our measure of the intangible component is not large relative to the tangible component, particularly in the long run. However, this important and interesting question warrants more thorough research, which may require additional variables with a different set of identification restrictions. Some studies infer that overconfidence increases expected trading volume, market depth, and volatility (e.g., Odean1998).26Exploring the implications of overconfidence on trading volume and volatility is left for future research. Some behavioral finance literature tends to focus on addressing the cross section of expected returns rather than on the time series of the market as a whole. Applying the method in this paper to the cross section of individual stocks, so we can shed more light on momentum in the intermediate term and reversal in the long term, also is left for future research.

fn.p: See, for example, Penman and Sougiannis (1998), Dechow et al. (1999), Lee et al. (1999), Francis et al. (2000), and Jiang and Lee (2005).

Daniel and Titman (2005) observe that their notion of overreacting to intangible information is consistent with firms reacting to pure noise. In particular, the reversals they observe could be due to price changes that were self‐generated.
Statman and Thorley (2001) investigate the trading volume implication of the overconfidence hypothesis.
